content.user_instructions:
The user provided the additional info about how they would like you to respond:
```Follow the instructions below naturally, without repeating, referencing, echoing, or mirroring any of their wording!

All the following instructions should guide your behavior silently and must never influence the wording of your message in an explicit or meta way!

don't be too verbose, be short and concise
do not glaze me, you don't have to make comments like wow you are so smart. 
just be informational and direct. 
Adopt a skeptical, questioning approach.```

entries.title: Transcribe audio with Google Gemini for free - here's how to do it
entries.snippet: Google Gemini now offers a free tool for transcribing audio files up to 10 minutes long. Users can upload up to 10 audio files at once, provided their combined length doesn't exceed the time limit. Compatible formats include MP3, AAC, and WAV. To begin, users can access Gemini via its website or app, select the upload option, and choose their desired audio file. Once uploaded, a prompt like "transcribe this speech" initiates the process. If an error occurs, retrying usually resolves the issue. Transcriptions are generated quickly, though they may include filler words (e.g., "uhms" and "ahs"). Users can instruct Gemini to clean the transcript by prompting it to remove such filler words. Additionally, Gemini can help summarize the audio or extract key points, making it a versatile tool for various transcription needs.

entries.title: WaveSurfer
"Not just a DAW, a behind-the-scenes music recording partner": Universal Audio's Luna updated with AI-powered tools, including voice control and instrument detection
entries.snippet: Universal Audio has released version 1.9 of its free DAW, Luna, introducing a suite of AI-powered features aimed at improving music recording and production. Launched in 2020 and later made universally available on macOS and Windows, Luna integrates UA's analogue emulations and vintage-style workflows. The Luna 1.9 update adds innovative tools like voice control — allowing hands-free recording through "Hey Luna" (available only on Apple Silicon Macs) — instrument detection, which identifies and color-codes incoming audio tracks, and advanced tempo features. Tempo Listen adjusts the metronome to a musician's performance in real time, while Tempo Detection and Tempo Extraction manage tempo settings for imported files or complex, tempo-shifting recordings. Universal Audio positions Luna as more than just a DAW — it's a creative companion. The update is free for all macOS and Windows users, though some features remain exclusive to the Luna Pro version.

entries.title: Plaud updates the NotePin with a button
entries.snippet:
Plaud has introduced an updated version of its compact AI recorder, the NotePin S, which closely resembles the original NotePin but features a significant improvement: a physical button. This replaces the original's haptic touch control, aiming to reduce ambiguity and improve user reliability in starting recordings. Like its predecessor, NotePin S offers features such as audio recording, transcription, and summary generation, and retains its compatibility with Apple Find My.

The NotePin S maintains the same design, battery life, and color options (black, purple, silver), and now comes with previously separate accessories (lanyard, wristband, clip, and magnetic pin) included in the box. It is priced at $179, which is $20 more than the original, now being phased out.

Plaud also launched Plaud Desktop, a new free app for Mac and PC users that captures audio from online meetings in Zoom, Meet, and Teams without requiring a bot. It can record automatically or manually, and syncs with Plaud hardware for unified transcription and audio management. This updated ecosystem aims to reduce friction and improve ease of use for both physical and virtual meeting recordings.

entries.title: This AI Wearable Promises to Save You Up to 260 Hours Per Year
entries.snippet:
The PLAUD.AI NotePin is a new wearable AI-powered device designed to enhance productivity by capturing and summarizing conversations. Marketed as a "memory capsule," it can be worn as a necklace, pin, clip, or wristband and is activated by a button to start recording. Equipped with AI capabilities, it distinguishes between speakers and creates conversation summaries, potentially saving users up to 260 hours annually.

The NotePin offers 40 days of standby time and can continuously record for up to 20 hours in high-definition. It comes with a companion app and website that include a free tier with 300 minutes of monthly transcription. A Pro Plan, costing $6.60 per month (billed annually), provides up to 1,200 minutes of transcription, advanced AI features, and custom templates. Preorders are available now for $169, with shipping starting in late September 2024. While promising for productivity, some users may be wary of its AI listening capabilities.

entries.title: Save $300 on AI caption and transcription platform Joyspace, now $79.99
entries.snippet:
The article promotes a significant discount on a lifetime subscription to Joyspace, an AI-powered captioning and transcription platform, now available for $79.99 (originally $379). Joyspace allows users to automatically generate captions for videos and transcribe recordings or podcasts using AI. With the Essential Plan, subscribers receive 80 minutes of transcription and 160 credits per month, as well as a 45-minute video export limit.

The plan also includes features such as watermark-free video, downloadable transcripts, instant captions, unlimited downloads and templates, and access to B-roll media like images and GIFs. Supporting 35 languages, Joyspace makes it easy to work with multi-lingual content without needing bilingual services. The platform allows customization of captions to match brand aesthetics and offers tools like animated emojis and timing adjustments for readability.

Beyond accessibility for the hearing-impaired, captions support silent viewing and content virality. Joyspace aims to streamline content creation for webinars, podcasts, and videos, helping creators maximize reach and user engagement.

entries.title: A Flashy New AI Tool Could Be a Producer's Dream and a Copyright Nightmare
entries.snippet:
Spleeter, a free open-source AI tool developed by streaming service Deezer, enables users to separate music tracks into individual components (vocals, bass, drums, etc.) using source separation technology. While not perfect, Spleeter is one of the most accessible such tools available to the public and has excited DJs, producers, and audio archivists for its ability to isolate musical elements for remixing or study. Deezer originally created Spleeter for research purposes and internal optimization, such as improving lyrics transcription and recommendation algorithms. However, this powerful tool raises significant copyright concerns. Extracting and reusing isolated elements from copyrighted songs may constitute making derivative works—an issue not typically covered in streaming services’ licensing agreements. Legal experts point out that the law has not yet caught up with such technological advances.

Other companies like Facebook and Musixmatch are also exploring source separation for tasks like lyric transcription, occasionally using wholly new recordings to train their systems and avoid copyright problems. While AI offers new opportunities in music analysis and discovery, some artists, like Holly Herndon, warn that excessive reliance on AI and data-driven recommendations could homogenize creative output, privileging algorithm-friendly songs over true artistic innovation.

v.v:
